title: 103_hr629
content: The Act may be cited as the "Improvement of Information Access Act of 1993". The Congress recognizes the importance of a well-informed citizenry, access to Government information, and the use of modern technology for citizens' benefit. Government information is a national resource and economic asset that belongs to the public, funded by taxpayers who should have affordable access without excessive fees. Government information is a valuable economic asset that belongs to the public. Taxpayers should not have to pay excessive fees for access. Federal agencies need to improve public input on information policies and develop standards for easier access. Many Federal agencies do not provide timely access to Government information products and services at reasonable costs, hindering public access. Improved public access to government information is addressed by adding a new chapter to Title 44, United States Code, focusing on information dissemination policies and practices. The new chapter in Title 44, United States Code addresses public access to government information by requiring executive departments to prepare and share reports on their information dissemination policies and practices annually. This includes plans for new information products, efforts to develop standards for easier information access, and more. The department or establishment is required to report on efforts to develop standards for easier information access, create comprehensive indexes, provide methods for public access, protect records stored with obsolete technologies, and promote awareness of information resources. The department or establishment must report on efforts to develop standards for information access, create indexes, provide public access methods, protect records stored with obsolete technologies, and promote awareness of information resources. This includes publishing a notice in the Federal Register annually with a summary of public comments and responses. The department or establishment must notify users of the availability of a report and allow a 90-day period for public comments on information dissemination policies and practices, including types of information collected, methods of dissemination, pricing, and information quality. The department or establishment must allow public comments on information dissemination policies and practices, pricing, and information quality. Comments received will be available for public inspection, and there will be opportunities for dialogue between agency officials and the public. Agencies must also provide a reasonable opportunity for dialogue before discontinuing an information product or service. Before discontinuing an information product or service, an agency must publish a notice for public comments, provide reasons for the discontinuation, and consider the comments received. Each agency is required to disseminate information through various modes and outlets to meet statutory requirements. Each agency must disseminate information through diverse modes and outlets to reinforce statutory requirements for distribution. Information must be timely, useful, and reliable, stored in standardized formats, and distributed through channels that ensure free or low-cost public access. Agencies are prohibited from discontinuing information products without public notice and consideration of comments, except as authorized by statute. The agency must use various distribution channels to provide free or low-cost public access to government information. They are not allowed to charge depository libraries for distributing information or charge more than the incremental cost of distribution. No royalties or fees can be charged for the use or redistribution of government information. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for agencies to provide public access to records. Agencies must provide public documents upon request within a specified timeframe. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for providing access to agency records under section 4101(f) of title 44, United States Code.
